title: Prince George's christening gown was dyed with Yorkshire Tea to get colour just right
text:

Prince George, Princess Charlotte, Prince Louis and their cousin Archie all wore the same stunning ivory gown when they were officially welcomed into the church at their christening.

The intricate lace and satin piece is an exact replica of one which has been worn by all royal babies since 1841.

In 2004 the Queen decided the original had become too fragile to use, so asked for a new one to be made for future generations.

Her dressmaker and friend Angela Kelly was given the important task, and reveals in her new book that she got the colour just right dying it in Yorkshire Tea.

Accompanied by dresser Barbara Buckfield, Angela travelled to Italy to find the perfect lace for the new gown carrying the priceless original in her handbag.

(Image: PA)

She writes: "Together, we sourced lace to complement that being made in Italy, and to make sure it looks authentic we dyed it in Yorkshire tea (the strongest, as we all know).

"We placed each piece of lace in a small bown, from the Dressers' kitchen, filled with cool water and a tea bag, and left it for about five minute, checking regluaraly until the colour was perfect."

Angela showed the Queen the gown at each stage of the process, which took about nine months.

"Her Maesty was very interested to see how it was developing."

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

The Earl and Countess of Wessex's son Viscount Severn became the first to wear the new robe at his christening in 2008.

Since then Zara and Mike Tindall's children and the Cambridge and Sussex kids have all worn it for their special days.

Baptisms are a must for Windsor babies as the Queen is Defender of the Faith and Supreme Governor of the Church of England.

Royal infants are often welcomed into the Christian faith within weeks of being born.

George was christened when he was three months old, while Charlotte was only nine weeks, Archie two months and Louis was 11 weeks.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: Royal Collection Trust)

George was the first future monarch in modern times not to be baptised at Buckingham Palace, with the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge choosing the intimate Chapel Royal at St James's Palace instead in 2013.

He was on his best behaviour, blowing bubbles beforehand and being quiet and peaceful afterwards.

Princess Charlotte was christened at the Church of St Mary Magdalene at Sandringham in Norfolk in 2015.

She was pushed to her christening past well-wishers in a vintage 1950s silver-wheeled Millson pram - once used for the Queen's youngest children Prince Andrew and Prince Edward - and began to cry ahead of the service before being settled by the duchess.

(Image: PA Archive/PA Images)

Prince Louis's baptism also took place at the Chapel Royal in 2018.

He was well behaved, staying sound asleep as he was carried into the chapel by Kate.

Charlotte was heard telling off photographers and declaring they were not allowed inside following the service.

Meghan Markle and Prince Harry made Archie's christening a private affair, now allowing well-wishers and media to wait outside to be part of the special day.

However they released a number of cute photos to mark the occasion, showing their gorgeous little boy in the traditional gown.
description: Kate Middleton and Meghan Markle's children all wore the intricate lace and satin gown for their christening, made by the Queen's dressmaker Angela Kelly
